I made this exactly as stated ingredient-wise, but used a bundt pan for 55 min.  After reading another reviewer's comment that it didn't need frosting, I served this without. userID:

Display Name:
lisangus

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a New Year's potluck dinner Dec 31 2008. I used all the recommendations of gneebeanie (she consolidated the amendments of 1600+ reviews.) I too got rave reviews and people wanting seconds. However, to my mind it was a bit too sweet and fragrant -- another time I would revert to the original 2 tsp cinnamon and 2 tsp vanilla (she recommended increasing each to 3) and would cut down a bit on the sugar, both in the cake and in the icing (though I only iced the top, as I brought it still in the 9x13 pan -- if I had turned it out and iced all around I'd probably need the whole icing recipe.) I also incorporated the walnuts (instead of pecans) into the cake rather than putting on the icing, though it could be both. 
It was easy to make, however, and made a lovely, moist, chewy cake that was enjoyed even by people who said they don't usually like carrot cake.

text:
Yummy!  This was great!  I scoped out the other reviews and went with the majority.  Applesauce for 50% of the oil.  Dash of nutmeg.  Upped the vanilla.  Added a small can of crushed pineapple (drained).  I also added some extra shredded carrot - just because I had so many in my produce basket!  It came out super moist and super delish.  After my husband - who isn't a huge fan of carrot cake to begin with - polished off a layered round, I made some loafs to pop into the freezer for emergencies.

text:
I've received great reviews from everyone who has tasted this cake. I have followed others advice and slightly altered the cake and it's absolutely perfect.  I reduced the oil to 3/4 c. canola and substituted the rest (1/2 c.) with unsweetened apple sauce. Instead of 2 cups white sugar, I used 1 c. white sugar and 1 c. brown.  Also, for the frosting, I reduced the confectioners sugar to 2 cups.  It's sweet enough with just 2 cups. Wonderful! Thank you.

text:
I had to use 2 cups of whole wheat flour in this recipe instead of the all-purpose flour because that's all that was in the house. That's why I'm giving it four stars...I did not find the recipe as moist as others have described and the cake seemed dense--i assume this is because of the w.w. flour. The other changes I made based on the other reviews I've read: 1c brown sugar/1 c white, extra tsp vanilla, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, extra tsp cinnamon and 3/4 c canola/1/2 cup applesauce instead of 1 and 1/4 cups of oil. The flavor of the cake is very good, I just don't think it's as moist as I expected. Will definitely try again with white flour.

The icing is excellent--I used 3 cups of confectioners' sugar instead of 4 and didn't add nuts to the icing because I felt there were enough nuts in the cake already.

My mom & aunt love it though--but they are health buffs.

Wow... I messed up.  I scaled the reciepe for 30 and instead of 3/4 teaspoon of salt I put in 1 Tablespoon.  I was preparing the dry mix so I could assemble the next day when I realized my mess.  I just added enough mixture for 90 servings to help keep it from tasting like a salt bomb.  Next day I began to make the cake with shredded carrots I picked up from the 99 Cent store.  it was like making a box cake it was so easy.  I ran out of oil so I used 3/4 cup of crisco butter flavor and 1 cup oil.  Then I used splenda 1 cup and 1 cup of sugar.  First time with out pineapple the cake was sooooo good the crust was kind of stick crunch taste it was my best.  However it fell in the middle not used to that.  Thank you for the sharing the recipe.

userID:
3372597
Display Name:
Kyra

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/150803.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe! I also made it with the few changes suggested by many of the reviewers here and the cake turned out wonderfully - taste and texture. I was actually happy you can't really taste the carrots inside, the cake simply has that nutty/carrot cake flavor, moist and so very yummy. I guess everybody has his/her preference when it comes to food.

As far as oven time, my cake took about 1 hour and a half to bake (which made me worry a bit about the success of this cake) but I realized that I made a mistake that could have lead to a baking disaster. Since my oven does not have a way to set or control temperature, I have to use guessing when it comes to baking. Well, the temperature was higher and it caused the cake to crust faster on the outside but not bake properly on the inside. When I realized this was the issue, I turned the heat down but it had to bake way longer then the time the recipe stated. So if your cake starts burning on the sides but does not cook in the center, high oven temperature must be the issue: simply turn it down a tad and let it bake longer.

I also made sure to grate the carrots on the side of the grater used for cheese, so I had no problems with carrot lumps or juices.

This cake raises quite a bit while in the oven, so make sure you put it in the right size pan to avoid spilling-over.

My only wish is that the frosting would be stiffer (I used 3 cups of sugar) so I can decorate the cake for more of a festive Christmas dinner.

text:
I didn't rate it five stars, because I had to do some modifications. Once I did that then the carrot cake turned out great. I followed others' reviews and use less oil (I used 1 cup instead of 1 1/4 cup). I would like to use apple sauce, but I didn't have any on hand so next time I will use 3/4 cup oil and 1/2 cup apple sauce). When making the frosting I used less powdered sugar (I used 3 cups instead of 4). After I frosted my carrot cake with a fair amount of frosting, I still have a lot left over. Next time I will cut the butter in half (use 1/4 cup instead of 1/2 cup) and cut the powered sugar in half as well (use 2 cups instead of 4 cups). After the cake is frosted, I sprinkled finely chopped pecans on it...it looks so much better than just plain white frosting. I made a 9 x 13 cake.

country:

text:
OK. THIS CAKE IS THE REEEEEEEAL DEAL. 
this is THE SINGLE BEST CARROT CAKE IN THE WORLD. 
I have tried it just as the recipe says, and with little modifications. 
It was fabulous both times, but I prefered the texture with my changes. 
Use 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white. If you like a perfect smooth texture grate your carrots. If you like to see the carrots, then grate them thicker!
My only problem with this cake is that it is a bit too greasy. but its wonderfull so next time im going to use 3/4 cups vegetable oil and 1/2 cup applesauce.  
As for the frosting, 2 cups of sugar is enough.. the cake is pretty sweet and is perfect without the frosting
Oh! you can also use chopped walnuts instead of pecans. 
update: I made cupcakes with this recipe, they came out great! I halved the recipe and had 15 normal sized cupcakes! oh! and I never have that problem with the extra liquid grating the carrots!  i think the texture is great!

text:
Super carrot cake, and easy to make too.   After reading reviews I added an extra tsp. of vanilla and an extra tsp. of cinnamon and it was perfect.  I also replaced the nuts with 1 c plumped raisins.  To me it's not carrot cake without raisins!!!  I just plumped them in a saucepan on med. heat.
The cake was very moist but did brown on the edges before it was fully cooked.  It didn't interfere with the taste of look of the cake though.  I did notice it didn't quite rise all the way in the middle, as others had mentioned ~ but once again, it didn't mess up the cake.  It was a great cake and the person I made it for said it was the best carrot cake they had ever had in all their 81 years!
I used the Cream Cheese Frosing II ~ Not to sugary and really creamy and wonderful.

text:
This cake is amazing! Wow. This is the first time I made carrot cake. I shredded almost a full bag of small carrots to make 3 cups. I also added a dash of all spice and a small amount of cloves. I did not have vegetable oil, so I used corn oil and I didn't add salt because I didn't have any. The icing recipe is on this site, but the confectioners sugar is half the amount. I prefer it that way. It tastes perfect! I think 3 or 4 cups would be too sweet. I did add the pecans on top, but just a little for a nice presentation. Thanks for sharing!
Made again on Easter withour realizing I've used this recipe before. EXCELLENT!! But this time I added 2 (8oz.) cream cheese to the frosting and a capful of vanilla extract. Then the icing was perfect!!! The icing is not good as written, it's way too thick and sweet. This recipe is delicious.

text:
My boyfriend loved this recipe!  I went ahead and used some of the previous suggestions like: substituting half of the vegetable oil with apple sauce and adding  one can of crushed pineapple to it.  I noticed that when I used crushed pineapple that it increased the moistness of the cake compared to the second time when I did not add the pineapple.  I also used 1 cup of white sugar and 1 cup of brown sugar and added 1 tsp of nutmeg.  The amount of powdered sugar was too much for the cream cheese frosting so I only used 2 cups, which made it much better!

text:
This is a great recipe! My first time making carrot cake and it came out really good. I would do the following tweaks for it to be perfect. Cake: More cinnamon, vanilla, swapped some applesauce for oil(you can alter portions as needed), nutmeg, ginger, allspice or pumpkin pie spice(these as liked for really good flavour), tad more carrots and didn't have pecans so used walnuts. Icing: Use LESS sugar(about 2 cups and add to taste). I think it should taste cheesier but the recipe icing was very, very sweet. A great recipe that I will make again!

text:
I am giving this recipe 4 stars because I made some changes to make it a 5 star recipe. First off, I did as other reviewers and changed the 2 cups of white sugar to 1 cup white and 1 cup brown. Also for the 2 cups of flour, I used 1 cup whole wheat flour and 1 cup white. For the oil I used 1/2 cup cinnamon applesauce, 1/3 cup oil, 3 Tbsp of milled flax seed, and about another 1/4 cup of the shredded carrots. I also added another teaspon of cinnamon, added alittle nutmeg and cloves. So I changed the recipe quite a bit but there was so much flavor to it this way. I also almost 1/2 the powdered sugar in the frosting to be able to taste the cream cheese more. This cake went fast in my house. I am sure the original recipe would too, however I had to cut back on that oil and make it alittle more healthier, not much though!!

text:
Like some of the other reviewers, I am confused as to why this cake has received such high marks from so many.  My cake turned out dense and dry and I don't think that it was anything that I did.  I used 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar and I substituted 1/2 c applesauce for 1/2 c of the oil.  I also added a little nutmeg.  I used 3 1/2 cups of powdered sugar for the icing because that was all that I had on hand, and decided that it needed a lot more, due to being very runny.  I don't know how some cooks are getting by with less.  The cake had a good taste, just not a very good texture.  I was hoping for a lighter cake.  I will keep trying to find the perfect recipe.

text:
Thought I'd add my 2 cents to the pile of positive reviews.  Fantastic!
Added a 1/4 tsp. nutmeg for a bit more spice, and replaced some of the oil for applesauce.  
This is the first cake I've ever made where I was tasting the batter before it was cooked!  I've never made carrot cake before and I'm glad I tried it.  
Unlike almost everyone else, I ADDED sugar to the frosting to make it a bit sweeter.

The only issue I had is that the frosting makes WAY too much!  I got 2 cakes using loaf pans and I have about 3 cups frosting left over.

text:
Loved this recipe!  I did read other reviews and did make some adjustments that others made.  I used half brown sugar and half white sugar, 1 can of crushed pineapple without the juice, and added an extra teaspoon of cinnamon.  I think this cake is probably great without adding these things and I agree with one reviewer that you should rate the recipe as is without adding substitutions, but, I love pineapple and thought it would add to the moistness of the cake.  I made this for friends as a trial to a bridal shower cake I am making this weekend and it was a big hit.  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
I was looking for a carrot cake recipe to make for
my dad for Father's day, and boy did I find one! I
see why this recipe is so highly rated, it's so good.
Followed the recipe to a tee, other than using half
brown sugar and half white sugar (as others have
shared), and pumpkin spice for the cinnamon. And,
I left the nuts out of the frosting and just sprinkled
them on top. The frosting is easier to spread that
way. Five stars and highly recommended!

text:
Fantastic cake!  Carrot cake is my dad's favorite so I made it for him, he LOVED it!
I only made a few changes, mostly after reading numerous reviews:  added 1/4 tsp nutmeg, used 3 tsp cinnamon, used walnuts instead of pecans, used 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugar, and for the frosting I only used 1/4 cup butter, 2 cups sugar, and omitted the nuts, though I may try those next time. All in all, a wonderful cake!

text:
The cake turned out beautifully. I was grossed out by the idea of using so much oil, so instead I used 1/4 cup veg oil and 1 cup of applesauce. 

I also subbed whole wheat flour, and for the sugars I used 1 c. sucanat and 1 c. turbinado. I added about 10 oz of crushed pineapple and 1 cup of raisins.

Superb.

text:
This was the BEST!  I took others' advice and used 1/2 oil, 1/2 applesauce, 1 cup whitesugar, 1 cup brown sugar, added nutmeg and extra cinnamon, used walnuts instead of pecans.  I made this in 2 round cake pans, baked at 350 for 35 minutes and they were perfect!!  I did not make the frosting in this recipe, I used a different cream cheese frosting from this site.  The only change I will make next time is to cut back on the walnuts a bit and NOT add them into the frosting. This was very dense and moist and full of flavor.

Tastes like a carrot cake.  Nothing spectacular.  I found the amount of spices a little overwhelming.  Also, I only used about 2.5 cups powdered sugar for the frosting and it was plenty sweet.  It didn't have that "carrot cake frosting" taste I was looking for.  Just tasted like a sugar frosting.

If you're looking for an average recipe, this is it.  Nothing wrong with it, just average.

text:
I needed another dessert for Easter dinner, and I went looking for a carrot cake recipe to make cupcakes from.  I used this one because it didn't call for pineapple.  I halved it and made it almost exactly as the recipe was, except I added a little nutmeg and allspice.  I halved the icing recipe, as well (and had a ton left).  I watched them as they baked, and the cupcakes took about 22 minutes - they were AWESOME.  I won't be changing this recipe at all.  My father actually called me just yesterday to tell me that he was made "because the cupcakes you made were terrific and you only sent me one home!"

text:
I will never buy a carrot cake from the bakery again!!!  This was a smashing hit with everyone at my Easter Dinner table!  First carrot cake recipe I ever tried and the only one I will ever use!    I made a few changes to the original recipe to help us cut out some fats and calories.   Heres my changes: 
In place of the oil I used about 3/4 cup oil, 1/2 cup applesauce, added a can of drained crushed pinapples, replaced the sugar with Splenda.  For the frosting I reduced the sugar by about a cup.  Also used two 8 inch cake pans and baked for 35 minutes.     Delicious!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The carrot cake itself was excellent however the frosting wasn't what I was hoping for so when making it a second time I had to make up my own frosting recipe to get that traditional carrotcake taste, so only 4 stars from me due to that. I also cooked the cake in two 9 inch round pans for 35 min. and they turned out great. The first time I made the frosting I decided to double the recipe to ensure I'd have enough for a stacked cake and I got about 3 cups of sugar into the mix with 2 pkgs of cream cheese and decided that was more than enough. It was already over sweet and I can't imagine what it would've been like if I went with all 8 cups of sugar. It wouldn't have been the traditional carrotcake creamcheese icing flavor just an extra sweet sugar frosting. After making the cake a second time I found 2 packages of cream cheese and 2 cups of sugar and 1/8 cup of butter was my perfect frosting for a round stacked cake. It was fantastic that way!

text:
This is a great recipe.  It's the first time I've made carrot cake and I like it.  I used the other members modifications and also used a Splenda sugar mix for the white and brown sugar (1/2 cup Splenda sugar mix = 1 cup sugar).  I also added a cup of raisins, and used walnuts instead of pecans.  No pecans in the frosting either, and I just used 3 cups of sugar, because I like my carrot cake frosting really tart.  I'll use this recipe again!

country:
None
text:
Isn’t this the way it always goes? Hubby eyeballs the purchase of a pretty (and expensive) carrot cake, displayed in the grocery at Easter. I veto it, but tell him I would make one. Then I find out he’s not sure if he even likes carrot cake! But he did like this one. It came out beautifully. I don’t do much baking. Sweets as a constant around the house only add to the waistline and the grocery budget these days is better spent on food for meals instead of treats. I made the cake and the icing exactly as the recipe said but left out the pecans. Great recipe, not too difficult, tastes great. Mildly spiced, I personally might try varying it next time using some brown sugar, more vanilla and maybe some nutmeg as others suggested. I was trying to remember that it was carrot CAKE and not a spicy sweet bread like pumpkin or banana bread. Also I don’t usually comment about the timing shown in the recipe because I rarely keep track, always marred by distractions and interruptions and cleanup anyway. For the goof this once I did time myself from greasing the pan to the time I popped the pan into the oven. It was EXACTLY 30 minutes like it says. That included shredding the carrots and almost all the getting out and putting away the ingredients and cleanup of the prep utensils. (Not making the icing though. That whipped up fast and yummy, in no time, later.) I’ll make this cake again. Hubby ate 2 pieces!

followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
20
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/49136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was possibly the best cake I've ever made! My husband loved it. Incredibly moist and airy...not dense at all!
I made considerable alterations to the recipe, which I've listed below. It was a bit of work, but definitely worth it. I used the cream cheese frosting recipe provided as a guide, but essentially made my own.

-instead of all that oil, I used 3/4 oil (canola) and made my own (unsweetened) applesauce to account for the 1/2 cup oil I omitted.

-1 cup white & 1 cup brown sugar

-1/4 tsp nutmeg added as well as a dash of ground cloves and allspice

-I used 2 cups of grated carrots and 1 cup of pineapple that I crushed up in the food processor. This made for really MOIST cake!

-**I separated the yolks from egg whites. Took the egg whites separately with a bit of the sugar (maybe 1/4 cup or less) and whipped them up until frothy with the hand mixer.  I added the yolks to the mix first and then at the very end I mixed in the whites. I think this is partially to credit for the fluffiness of the cake!

-I baked mine in 2 8" round pans (the disposable aluminum kind) that were greased & floured. I would have used parchment rounds in the bottom, but I was out of parchment..

-I found it took about 45 minutes in the oven, but I did elect to cook my cakes at about 325' instead as my oven runs on the hot side...

For the frosting:

-I used about 8.5 oz of cream cheese 

-I only used 1 1/2 cups of confectioner's/icing sugar.

-Added an additional 1/2 tsp of vanilla extract

-Om

text:
Carrot cake is my favorite, favorite cake ever and this recipe is awesome. I've never made one before (somehow) and was a little worried, but this was so easy...it's hard to make this one go wrong. I did cut the oil half and half with water (applesauce isn't something I can find here, unfortunately, but water worked just as well) and made the frosting with 1/2 powdered sugar, 1/2 splenda-like stuff. It came out amazing. Soft, moist, not too sweet. It was a definite crowd-pleaser...I took it to some friends' house for dinner and they asked to keep the leftovers and are seriously considering buying an oven just so I can teach them how to make it.

text:
Thanks so much for this awesome recipe! Even though I made adjustments, I found it the perfect base from which to work. Here is what I changed, if anyone is curious:

I don't have much of a sweet tooth, so reduced the sugar to a scant 1 cup and used original, unrefined Sucanat (minimally processed sugar with the molasses stream still intact) instead, which contributed a rich caramel quality as well as minerals. Also used 3/4 cup of melted sweet butter and about 3 tablespoons of virgin coconut oil for the "oil" portion, and it was plenty. I'm kind of a geek and grind my own flour, and in this case freshly ground 2 cups of organic soft white wheat berries after having soaked and dehydrated them the day before. Given the low gluten content, it made for a moist and tender cake. I added a couple of mashed Barhi dates to the mix, too. They have a distinct, maple-y flavour that complemented the rest of the ingredients beautifully. Definitely use organic carrots if they are available to you. 

Baked the cake for 40 minutes in a clear glass, 9" x 13" dish. It was cooked through and didn't sink in the centre. For the frosting, I parted with the recipe completely and used homemade neufchâtel (we have a dairy cow and the cheese was sitting around the refrigerator after I made it yesterday). If I'd had cream cheese on hand, I would have used it instead. But the slightly tangy taste of the creamy neufchâtel is really lovely against the gentle but dark sweetness of the cake. As for the swee

I would like to add that while using this recipe I baked it in a rectangular pyrex pan that I layered w/ aluminum foil for easy clean up afterwards, well when it baked It kind of bubbled over the pan which was my mistake and should've used a bigger pan, but the excess carmelized and I broke off a piece to taste it and it was like a tastey chewy cookie, so now I will take the batter from this recipe and fill a frosting bag and form cookies on a baking sheet and see how they come out, though I might add a pinch more flour to make better thicker, but I imagine it they will turn out to be very tasty cookies (just wanteed to share my discovery) thanks again for this wonderful cake recipe that I've already added to my recipe box for future use.

country:
None
text:
Brilliant cake!!  Of course, many of us tweak these recipes a bit, and here are my tweaks.  First, I didn't want a large cake, so I scaled it to half size using the servings & scaling button on the recipe page.  Though the scaled recipe still said to use a 9"x13" pan, I figured that was a mistake and used a 9"x9" pan.  I used the small holes on my grater and had no mush and no excess liquid.  It was fine!  I replaced a few tablespoons of the oil with applesauce, but next time I would try drained crushed pineapple.  And I used only half (again) of the sugar in the frosting -- it was lightly sweet, a bit tangy, and very creamy.  Delicious!  Froze the leftovers and they are great right out of the freezer!!

LOVED it!  It was such a big hit at Thanksgiving dinner tonight!  As others suggested, I made the following substitutions: 1) 1/2 c cinnamon applesauce and 3/4 c canola, 2) 1 c brown sugar, 1 c white sugar 3) used 3 t vanilla, but only 1 t cinnamon bc I used cinnamon applesauce, 4) 1/2 t nutmeg, 5) no nuts.  For the frosting, I only used 2 1/2 c sugar which was plenty.  Everyone loved this!  Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
Not perfect, but quite near... A bit too dry for my taste. The first cake was terrible, it just rised and rised an rised... and ran over from the pan. The second time I used only (2 tsp baking and) one teaspoon of baking soda. It still raised little too much. I baked the cake in two pans (diameters 9 and 11 inches) and piled them. I made 1,5 portion of frosting, which was a bit too much, and decorated with pink paste (confentioners sugar & black currant juice), the cake became awfully cute.

I used glutenfree flour mix as usual, margarine instead of oil and a lot of cinnamon.

text:
I followed the recipe as written, except for reducing the amount of confectioner's sugar to 2 1/2 cups instead of four.  I've had experience with frostings that are too sweet, so this recommendation made intuitive sense.  There was one segment of the cake--near the middle--which sunk in.  No problem; I just added more frosting on that portion to build it up to the same level as the rest of the cake.  Somebody will get an extra dose of frosting.  This cake and frosting are splendid (I could make a nice snack of frosting alone, mmm), individually and collectively.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made 1.5 portion of the cake recipe to fill two 9" round pans and make a double layered cake, witI swapped 1c white sugar for 1c brown sugar, and made the following additions: 1) 1.5 tsp cinnamon 2) 1.5 tsp vanilla extract 3) 1 well-drained 8oz. can of crushed pineapple 4) 3/8 tsp nutmeg.  It came out well in the oven putting the pans side by side & using the same baking directions.  Instead of the recipe's frosting, though, I followed the directions in Cream Cheese II frosting exactly; it made just enough frosting to generously coat the cakes and in between.  I tricked it out by spreading a can of dulce de leche (actually made by boiling an unopened can of condensed milk in water for 4 hours--no, it doesn't explode) on both layers.  It was a wonderful hit.  The cakes came out perfectly moist, not dense.  I think the trick here is to use large holes when grating the carrot, so you have large shreds to work with instead of pudding.

text:
I did two eight inch rounds and decreased the oil by about 1/4 cup, as some reviewers said it turned out oily. It was good, but I think next time I'll use the full amount of oil and possibly decrease the cooking time because I thought it was a little dry/ overdone...carrot cake is supposed to be very moist!  I also added about 1/8 c. brown sugar. Still, very good! My husband claims to hate carrot cake, and did not eat this when it was initially served, as he had a choice of two desserts. However, he called me at work the next morning after eating it for breakfast and raved about it. The following morning, upon finding that I had brought the rest of the cake to work, he called and complained because he couldn't eat it for breakfast again! 
I used a different cream cheese frosting recipe (from this site) which had a lot less sugar so I can't comment on the frosting here.

text:
I made this to bring to my in-laws for Easter dinner, and it was a big hit.  My husband and mother-in-law both proclaimed it the "best carrot cake they had ever had."  I did make a couple of small changes after reading through the reviews.  I used 1/2 cup of oil and 3/4 cup of applesauce instead of all oil, one cup of white sugar and one of brown instead of all white, added an extra tsp of cinnamon and a tsp of nutmeg.  With the frosting, I used 3 cups of sugar as I hate too-sweet frosting, and it turned out excellent.  I also used 2 round cake pans and made a layer cake instead of one flat sheet cake.  Excellent recipe that I will use again and again!  (My husband requested this on his birthday).

I baked the Carrot Cake III for a Ladies Luncheon and Fashion show sponsored by our Catholic Women's League.  I have never been successful with Carrot Cake recipes but this one was "EXCELLENT".  I reduced the vegetable oil to 3/4 cup, instead of 2 cups of white sugar I added 1 cup of white and 1 cup of brown sugar.  I added 1/2 tsp of nutmeg and a pinch of allspice.  I also added 1 cup of crushed drained pineapple.  Awesome recipe.  Will certainly bake again and have made it my favorite Carrot Cake. 
Thanks again!

text:
I chose this recipe because it was a simple carrot cake, without all the raisins and pineapple and extras.  
I did make a few modifications as per other reviews.  I added another tsp of cinnamon and 2 tsp of nutmeg.  Used 3/4 cup oil and 1/2 cup applesauce.  Used 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white.  Added an extra cup of grated carrot.  I also added the grated rind of one orange.  I omitted the nuts.
The cake was done to perfection in 50 mins.  The icing was delicious.  Everyone devoured this right away and gave it rave reviews!!

I couldn't believe how perfect this turned out! I made it for Easter brunch, and everyone adored it. I really hate using oil in recipes, especially so much, so I substituted the exact amount of oil with baby food prunes instead. It works like a charm, and cuts down so much fat! I also didn't add any nuts, and used a bit less icing sugar (I thought it might be too sweet). Overall, this was seriously awesome.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried with oil and applesauce, good healthwise and soft too, but overall the one with all oil had tremendous ovation. It is soo good, simply made and delish. Used self raising flour + 1 tsp baking powder and 3/4 brown sugar and the rest white; doubled the cinnamon and more vanilla, too. The frosting however is too sweet for me so I used 16oz cream cheese (room temperature), 2Tbs. butter, 2Tbs icing sugar and just add enough maple syrup (log cabin butter flavoured) - whipped thoroughly and it is so fluffy and thick, no lumps. Suggestions: Do try adding a bit of nutmeg powder too, or chopped crystallized ginger, or golden raisins, for a change. Thanks Tammy for posting it here. Real beauty. Love it.

I've tried several recipes for carrot cake and this one was the best.  As with other carrot cake recipes, I reduced the amount of oil down to 1/2 cup. Thanks, Tammy for a great recipe.

userID:
26714853
Display Name:
Hope M
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7482718.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AMAZING!! My husband requested it for his bday this year and said this may have been the best cake I've made, that means a lot!
I used another viewers suggestions: 1) using 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar 2) adding an extra teaspoon of vanilla extract 3) adding 1 8oz. can of crushed pineapple (I squeezed out most of the juice before adding it, I didn't want any extra fluids in the cake) 4) Added 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg 5) added 1 extra teaspoon of cinnamon 6) used 3/4 cup canola oil and 1/2 cup applesauce. The result came out incredibly delicious - the cake was very flavorful and moist. For the frosting, I only used 3.5 cups of powdered sugar, and it was more than sweet enough, with a nicely balanced cream cheese vs. sweet flavor.
*still, I cut down on sugar even more, I just did a heaping C of brown-it was plenty sweet!
for the frosting, next time I would use only 2C of powdered, it was way too sweet. 
This recipe is a keeper!!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I've been making this carrot cake for 11 years.  Had to bring something to my first ever work holiday potluck back in 2008.  Frantically googled and this is the first carrot cake recipe I found.  I had little to no baking equipment - mixed the frosting with a fork - it was a hit.   I've been making it for potlucks and family get togethers ever since.  It gets requested all the time.  I swap a little white flour for wheat, a little oil for apple sauce, and use walnuts instead of pecans.  I'm making it this week for a baking contest  - fingers crossed!

text:
First time ever making carrot cake from scratch. I don't bake much because bf is not big on sweets and I don't need all that sugar! Turned out to be the best carrot cake we've ever had and carrot cake is the only cake bf likes. He LOVED this and I did too. Halved the recipe and followed exactly EXCEPT did not add nuts and did not have a full cup of white sugar left. Used 1/2 white, 1/2 light brown. Baked in a glass 8x8 @ 325 for 38 minutes. Did not specify type of butter in frosting so used unsalted. A little goes a long way! Was amazing and will definitely make again!

text:
Made it as is (increased recipe by 50% to serve 27). The only thing I did differently was I added about 6 oz. of crushed pineapple and swapped out one of the 3 cups of white sugar for light brown sugar. SInce this was a birthday cake I used round/springform pans (1-6.5" and 1-9.5"). The larger pan certainly had to cook longer than the stated 40-50 minutes. 30 minutes in, the middle was still soupy (just like the batter was) and I panicked, but after about an hour it was cooked through. The cake was a hit at my daughter's birthday party!

I made it today. It was really good. I made a few modifications. Ran out of granulated sugar, so I used honey and it did nicely for making the cake.  The icing was good but a little too sweet for me. The recipe called for the whole bag (4 cups) of the confectioners sugar which made it super sweet.

All in all in was good recipe and I would make it again with a modification on the icing. The cake was so good that it would be no problem eating it by itself as well!

text:
Absolutely Incredible! This recipe far exceeds any other carrot cake my husband and I have ever eaten. Very moist and full of flavor! I added a smidge more cinnamon to the batter and also added cinnamon, unsweetened shredded coconut, and the pecans to the frosting while
mixing. I used about 1/2-3/4 of the amount of sugar required for the frosting because we prefer our frosting to be less sweet and it turned out to be the perfect level of sweetness to compliment the cake, which I baked as muffins and cupcakes! Definitely plan on making this recipe again, perhaps for Thanksgiving!

text:
Ok I don’t usually write reviews but I had to on this one. I normally do not like carrot cake but this was amazing just the way it was. I did it in 2 8in round pans for a layer cake and I didn’t put the pecans inside the frosting (the kids wanted it smooth to be able to decorate) but we sprinkled them on top in a pattern instead (a 2&5 yr old were decorating for Dad). Everyone raved about this cake and said it was the best they ever had. Again I changed NOTHING for the actual cake  itself and the pecans were just on top of the cake instead of folded in the frosting so pretty much the same.

text:
I made this recipe exactly as written, with no changes other than omitting the pecans from the frosting. 

The cake is wonderfully moist as is, and would make great muffins. Just the right amount of dense and light that I like in a carrot cake, and not all the extras that I don't (I dont care for raisins, pineapple or the like in my carrot cake). Just the right amount of spice. 

The frosting was just a tad sweeter than I like, I think next time I will reduce the powdered sugar by about half a cup next time.

city:

country:
None
text:
Overall, this is a really nice carrot cake recipe! I did notice that it was tricky to get out of the pan and just as hard to flip. It took a bit of effort, but I managed alright; you just have to be extra firm when removing it from the pan and light and quick when flipping it, as it appears to be prone to tear easily. The cake is moist and works beautifully with the cream cheese icing. I did add a teaspoon of nutmeg and about an eighth of a teaspoon of allspice to the cake mix, as I prefer my desserts to have a bit more spice than was in the original recipe. I would recommend this recipe highly and cannot wait to finish eating this cake!

text:
The flavor and texture were good, however I've used this recipe a few times and am not satisfied for a couple reasons. This cake is personally too sweet, especially because the cream cheese frosting is already very rich. Also, my layers always cave with this one and to level a carrot cake this chunky is difficult without taking off more than intended. This recipe is ok, but I'll be looking for another one next time.

text:
This was a really easy and yummy recipe. The cake was moist!  The first time I made it I thought it was too moist for MY liking but everyone really raved, I also wanted a little more spice to it (personal preference).  The 2nd time around I added some extra cinnamon and cooked it longer than the last time...too dry!  LOL. Don't time it.  When a toothpick comes out clean, it's DONE!  LOL  I made this in a 1" high half sheet pan and it fit like a dream!!  I wasn't a huge fan of the frosting but again, personal preference bc everyone else liked it LOL!!  I have already had several requests for this cake again. Great recipe!

I am a HUGE fan of carrot cake. The best I ever had was at 2 Sisters Deli in Mystic, CT. (They closed up shop and went away decades ago). Their carrot cake was moist and rich... And the closest I've ever come to that mouth-watering goodness was this recipe. It was so GOOD! It was dark and moist and flavorful with just the right amount of crunch from the nuts. Sure I spilled a little extra vanilla in (who doesn't?) but you really don't have to change a thing. This recipe is the real deal.

text:
I made what appear to be the standard substitutions: 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown, 1/2 cup applesauce in place of that much oil, extra vanilla and cinnamon as well as 1/4 tsp each of nutmeg and allspice. Used only 1/2 cup pecans and threw in 1/2 shredded coconut. Baked at 350 in two 9 inch pans for 40 minutes. PERFECTION. And hey, if the recipe is improved by crowdsourcing—why not?

It was so easy! I like my carrot cake simple, so I was happy to find a recipe that excluded the coconut, raisins, and pineapples. I suggest using a cup of brown and a cup of white sugar like the other reviewers suggest and shift the flour 3x to make the cake more fluffy. Made at the last second for my sister’s birthday instead of the box, and there was NO leftovers.

text:
This recipe got rave reviews but I did change it. Every single person present said it was the best, fluffiest, moist carrot cake they ever had. They were kind of freaking out. These are the changes I made:
Sub organic pure cane turbinado sugar
2 c carrot and 1 c zucchini
2 - 9 in rounds , 30-35 mins

Also, I think next time I will reduce the oil by 1/4-1/2 cup and try to replace it with applesauce b/c, oil. And I will only use 3/4 c nuts next time.

text:
I hate to be one of *those* people, but I did make a couple changes to this recipe. (But only a couple! This carrot cake recipe is totally solid on its own.) I added a lil' nutmeg to give the cake a bit more kick. I also reduced the amount of powdered sugar that was called for, partially because I wanted to retain more of the cream cheese flavor, but mostly just to reduce the amount of frosting that would be produced. (This recipe makes waaaayyyyyy too much frosting if you follow it.) The cake turned out really well. Highly recommend this recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5567700.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is pretty much perfect. I can't believe that I get constant requests from people to make carrot cake! Last time I made it, my mom told me that it was the only cake she'd ever eaten that was even better than the icing.

Like some other reviewers, I do half brown and half white sugar, and an additional teaspoon of vanilla. I also use cake flour instead of all purpose, to give it a moister texture. Also - and this is purely out of personal preference - I add about a cup of raisins, and a generous amount of ginger, which gives it a spicier taste, with hints of tart from the raisins. Even without any of those changes, though, it's a fantastic recipe.

None
text:
I adjusted ingredients and I heard rave reviews. 
I added 4 eggs.  I used SoftSilk cake flour.
 Instead of oil I used 4 small , individual cups of applesauce, about 1 cup and a scant more. 
I added a small can of crushed pineapple, juice included. 
I baked in a 13x 9 , following directions to use non stick spray, flour the bottom and use waxed paper.    
My oven runs hot so my time was less. 
The creme cheese frosting was super. 
I added shredded carrots and some pecans on top.  
I'm giving it 5 stars from the compliments.   It went so fast I never tasted it!  
Deeeelicious!

text:
This carrot cake is WAY TOO SWEET! It made me nauseous. I followed the recipe exactly, and I've definitely had better. The only thing I changed was that I used half the nuts it suggested (and it was still pretty nutty). Next time i will definitely tweak it a bit (or a lot), and use maybe half the sugar it says to put. After all, 2 whole cups of sugar is a lot for a 9x5 cake.. Especially for carrot cake. I think brown sugar would've been better, but definitely not 2 cups. I think the amount of vegetable oil was a lot too.. 1 & 1/4 cups? Geez, talk about heart attack. The frosting is even too sweet. I'm not a huge baker so I couldn't really tell how sweet it would end up being. It seemed like a lot of sugar from the beginning though. I feel like this recipe is just really unhealthy.. like I'm kind of afraid to eat it. I LOVE desserts and I'm a big foodie, but I'll tweak this recipe next time to make it healthier and less sweet (or I'll find a healthier recipe). If you like really sweet stuff, then this recipe is good the way it is... With a glass a milk for sure. But for me it tasted like I was eating sugar - in cake form. And I love cake. This recipe has good reviews but most of those five star reviews are from people who completely changed the recipe. That's so misleading! And I found this out AFTER I made it. So sad. What a waste. Why would you completely change the recipe and then give it five stars?! Makes no sense, people!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really authentic carrot cake, no raisins or pineapple. This is the same recipe that my grandmother used to make for me over 60 years ago & the one I still use to this day including the cream cheese frosting with the nuts in it instead of in the cake. It is delicious & dense, so if you want fluffy this is not for you. You can substitute a little of the oil with applesauce, but not too much or it changes the taste & becomes more like spice cake. My family loves it just the way it is, no changes.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Made the cake recipe as written, with the exception of the nuts since I thought I had them and didn't.  Family raved about it.  A few thought the addition of the nuts would be nice next time, but some liked it so much they said not to change it.  I did put less amount of sugar in the frosting, since we like more of the cream cheese taste to come out.  I used about 2 1/3 cups of sugar in it.  I made mine in 2 nine inch pans, cooked 37 minutes and they were great - no fall in the middle.  It is a rich, heavy cake so make sure you test it with a toothpick and take it out when the toothpick is clean.  I had my time set for 35 minutes then waited a few more till it was done.  Entire cake was eaten yesterday and my family wants another today!!!

text:
Okay, so I made this recipe with NO changes. I followed it exactly as the recipe was written. I am no beginner Baker, but I don’t make carrot cake often. I thought with a 4.5 star review and THOUSANDS of people making this recipe... why not? 

Here’s why not. This cake lacks in flavor. I mean SERIOUSLY lacks in flavor. The most flavor you get is from the pecans and the frosting. It’s not very good. Don’t get me wrong, it’s not a “bad” cake... but if you are looking for a flavorful carrot cake, this is NOT the cake for you. 

I won’t be making this recipe again. I’ve made it, it’s decent enough (Walmart carrot cake has more flavor than this recipe) but now I am off to find a better recipe.

I followed the recipe exactly, except added a 1/4 tsp nutmeg and replaced the sugar with 1 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar.

In 9 inch cake pans I used all of the batter except for a tiny tiny bit since some people said it overflowed. It cooked for about 38 minutes. I cut circles of parchment paper for the bottom of the pans and sprayed them with cooking spray. It slid right out perfectly.

It was so moist and delicious. Thank you for this very very delicious recipe.

text:
This carrot cake is awesome! I made two nine inch round layers, and it worked out perfectly. The amount of icing was just fine also, without any editing.  Instead of white sugar in the cake batter, I went with 1/2 c dark brown sugar and used coarse natural sugar for the remainder (think Sugar in the Raw). I loved the deeper flavor this imparted in the finished cake. Also, I added a couple tablespoons of honey in the icing which complimented the flavor profile of the cake. Overall, this recipe is a winner!

That was kind of a bummer.  Thus the 3 stars.

text:
This cake was very simple to make and wasn't gonna take as much time as I thought it would. The cream cheese frosting recipe was great, but it was a little too sweet for me and my family so I lowered it to 3 cups and a little less butter and cream cheese. The cake itself was really good and my family enjoyed it a lot. It was moist and didn't take a very long time to cool. One change I would make to the cake batter is to add a little less salt and vanilla, everything else was just perfect and it fit my tastebuds. I will definitely make this recipe again in the future :)

Easily the best carrot cake I've ever had. It was moist and delicious, and I loved how many nuts there were (I'm a nut fan though!)

The recipe made too much for my 9" round cake pans, so it overflowed. It stuck and tore a little to the pan when trying to remove it, but it wasn't noticeable once I put the icing on. Next time I'll sprinkle the pecans on top of the cake instead of mixing them into the icing.

text:
I made this recipe as it was written (unlike the seeming majority of reviewers, who altered It beyond recognition in many cases) and it came out delicious. I had to leave out the nuts because we have some no-nut people in our house, but otherwise I followed the directions exactly. This was a challenge for me because I thought the CUP of vegetable oil was really too much, and worried the cake would be greasy and heavy. However, the end result tasted like a restaurant dessert. I iced the entire thing with a traditional cream cheese frosting. I will definitely make it again, possibly reducing the oil content and adding some powdered ginger and nutmeg to boost the spiciness.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My boyfriend asked me to bake a carrot cake for his mother over Thanksgiving because it's her favorite. I had never made it before and looked up a few different recipes to make sure I didn't disappoint. I did tweak the recipe a little as listed below (changes/additions marked with ***). His mother said it's the best carrot cake she's ever had in her life!


Ingredients: 
4 eggs, 
3/4 cups vegetable oil***, 
1/2 cup of applesauce***, 
 8 oz crushed pineapple (drained)***,
 1 cups white sugar***, 
1 cup of brown sugar***, 
2 teaspoons vanilla extract,  
2 cups all-purpose flour, 
2 teaspoons baking soda, 
2 teaspoons baking powder, 
1/2 teaspoon salt, 
1 tablespoon ground cinnamon***,
1/4 teaspoon nutmeg***, 
3 cups grated carrots, 
1 cup butter, softened***, 
24 ounces cream cheese, softened***, 
6 cups confectioners' sugar ***, 
1 tablespoon vanilla extract***, 
1/2 teaspoon salt***

I LOVE this recipe. I decided to make it for my boyfriend and I for our little thanksgiving alone this year. And oh my god I think it’s the best thing I’ve ever baked! text:
I will start with saying that carrot cake is my favourite cake. I am sorry I did change the tiniest things mainly out of necessity. I used half white half brown sugar only because I strongly believe carrot cake needs the caramelly flavour of brown  in it. I was making it with a 7 year old who doesn't like nuts so I added chocolate chunks (not necessary in my opinion but they worked beautifully) and because I was playing at the same time with said 7 year old I FORGOT to put in the cinnamon. I could have kicked myself and I put some on top while the cake was cooling before frosting it. I have to say in spite of this it was still one of the best carrot cakes ever. Beautifully moist and delicious and the texture was perfect. I preferred it the next day when the frosting had really set. I actually don't think I'd use another recipe thank you so much!!

After I took over making it for Easter, I substituted 1/2 c. of the oil for apple sauce, because as an adult, I didn't like that oily texture.   It took out the oily feel without sacrificing moisture or taste.  My family still loves it and looks forward to it every Easter :)

text:
Everyone in the family loved this one, right down to the dogs who stole the rest of the pecans off the pantry shelf. I used the 3 cups of carrots, I also used 1 cup of brown sugar & 1 cup of white sugar. I also took the advice of other users and used half a cup of Whipping Cream. I had to get the kids from school so It sat in the fridge for about 4 hours. I didn't find the frosting to be too runny. It was really nice, really light and fluffy! I live at 9,200 ft so I added two tbs of extra flour. Next time I will adjust and add vanilla pudding to keep it a little more moist at this altitude.

text:
Wow! Excellent cake!  I didn't change anything, except skipping nuts in cake batter, and only adding them to outer vertical edge of the frosting.  I also stacked two nine inch rounds, but I don't consider that a recipe change.  I wanted to rate the recipe as is, though it was tempting to make changes after reading other comments, but honestly, it was so good as is, that I'll do the same thing next time I make it.  I failed to grease my pans before flouring, because I used silicone pans, and my cakes stuck a little in the corners, my bad.  I'll add an update after serving it to my mother for her birthday in two days. She requested a carrot cake with cream cheese frosting, and this was perfect (and relatively simple)!  Thank you so much!!!

 Here are a few changes I made;
1)  separated egg whites, beat to stiff peaks and fold in egg whites at the end of the recipe. 
2) replace 1/2 cup of olive oil with one stick of butter 
3)added 1/2 cup of chopped golden raisins

text:
I've made this recipe twice, at the same time. My dad is celiac, so I made a gluten free version, and a regular version, and honestly, the gluten free version came out much better. It was denser (most gluten free baked goods tend to be) but it also didn't have the "airy" or strong baking powder taste the regular ones had. They also tasted a lot sweeter. I'm not sure why, because I followed the recipe to a T for both, besides using gluten free flour. My suggestion would be to probably add less baking soda and powder, or up the sweetness a touch ?

I've made this cake 3 times now. It's so amazing! I don't change a single thing. To all the people saying this recipe is terrible, dry, and doesn't cook correctly is just doing it wrong. Gotta layer those flavors, and not over mix. I also think doing 2 - 9" rounds is much better then a 9x13 every time. Never just set your timer and forget all about your cake, let the cake tell you when its done. I have to cook mine like 10 mins less.

text:
I made this this past weekend and it was a huge hit!!!! I made the recipe as is, except I didn't use all of the sugar in both the cake and the icing that the recipe called for. I probably only used about 1 1/2 cups of sugar in the cake and about 2 cups of the confectioner's sugar in the icing. Four cups seemed like it would be too sweet and it tasted just fine with half the sugar. Also, I used walnuts instead of pecans, as I had those on hand. 
My only critique is I think it needs more spice. Next time, I may try adding a little nutmeg. Will definitely make again!

text:
This carrot cake is delicious and my favorite!  I always am complemented on my baking skills (little do they know:))  I dont alter the recipe much except adding a bit more cinnamon, reducing the oil by 1/4 cup, and making sure the 3 cups of carrots are packed full.  The result is the best carrot cake I have ever tasted!!  The only problem I have come across is the cream cheese frosting--we dont have philadelphia cream cheese here in Turkey so I have to use Labneh.  It runs all over the place when I go to spread it, but once it stays in the fridge for a night the final outcome is delish!  Thank you for sharing  a recipe that  is a must to pass on to my daughter!

text:
Bugs Bunny's mom would take notes on how to make this truly delicious cake. I followed Dneebeanie recommendations: 1. Half white sugar half brown sugar 2. Use 3 1/2 cups of powdered sugar in the frosting mix 3. Added 8 oz. can of crushed pineapple which I drained and I didn't add pecans to the frosting just the cake. I used the larger holes on the grater to grate the carrots  as other reviewers suggested. I baked it in an 9x13 pan. The finished product made me scream "Holy Carrots"! It's that good. Carrot cake is not my go to - but it was Easter and my family loves it so had to give this one a go. Glllllaaaaaaaad I did. Even my kids liked it and what kid likes carrot cake?? Do yourself a favor and make this cake and don't skip the frosting. This is the best cream cheese frosting I've ever had. Will use this for a red velvet cake I foresee in the future.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe!!! Not only do I love it, but everyone I have made this for loves it. Thank you so much for posting it. It's such an amazing and versatile cake!
I have made this a bunch of times, I've baked it using the recipe as is, I've made it using vegan ingredients and I have made it using recommendations from other reviews. The big changes I made were mostly done for personal preference. I followed Gnee Beanie's recommendations and in addition I added a handful of shredded coconut to the cake mix and frosting. Finally,  I decorated it by loosely piling some carrots that have been candied in brown sugar and maple syrup and then curled around the handle of a spoon. (Super easy! I used a recipe from Epicurus)
I'd like to offer some  cake advice, When you take your cake pan out of the oven, let it rest for a minute, then put the pan in the freezer for 15-20 minutes to cool. This makes cakes, fantastically moist and it pops out of the pan when you're ready to ice it. No more cracks!
Despite the all the changes I've made, this really is the most amazing carrot cake I've ever had! Thank you so much for posting it.

I broke a personal rule, based on reviews I altered the original recipe the first time I made it . The recipe sounded yummy however, I knew it had too much oil and sugar for my family's diet.  As suggested: combo of white/brown sugar, substituted applesauce for some of the oil, extra spices, drained pineapple. After all the additions, I found I needed to add an extra cup of flour. The cake was DELICIOUS! Extremely moist and flavorful. 
I agree with a comment made, someone needs to post the revised recipe as Carrot Cake IV.  It's a keeper!

text:
My 12 year old made this recipe today and followed it exactly as  it was stated. She's not a big improviser and doesn't eyeball ingredients so everything was measured to a tee. The biggest problem we encountered was that she filled the 9x13 pan as instructed in the recipe and put it in the oven.  I checked in on it about 15 minutes into baking and it was bubbling over.  It had a strange fizzing quality that I attributed to too much baking soda. I rechecked her amount and she assured me she used only what was in the recipe.  It was liquid enough that I used a ladle and scooped out about 2 cups of batter . 2 cups of batter too much? It had almost a foamy quality so once it settled it wasn't actually 2 cups but baking in the oven it would have continued overflowing.  I don't know what was wrong but I'm guessing something between baking soda and/or baking powder reacting to something in the recipe? 
Taste: It tastes good! A little bland for my particular carrot cake taste but good texture and moisture! A  little clove, all spice, nutmeg, or more cinnamon wouldn't have hurt. Mainly I just didn't appreciate the emergency of scooping out hot batter before it dripped all over my oven.  Anybody else had this happen? Thanks.

country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! I made a few changes per the most helpful review that I read and this turned out amazing. My family was raving about it and they are very honest! Here is what I did different:
1) using 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar 
2) adding an extra teaspoon of vanilla extract 
3) Added 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg 
4) added 1 extra teaspoon of cinnamon 
5) used 3/4 cup canola oil and 1/2 cup applesauce. 

For the frosting, I only used 3-3.5 cups of powdered sugar, and it was more than sweet enough, with a nicely balanced cream cheese vs. sweet flavor. Aldo use large cheese grater to grate the carrots!

This is essentially the same recipe I use; I got mine from Better Homes and Gardens cookbook, and mine doesn't call for pecans (of course you can add them in, or walnuts would be good too). Display Name:
e-cakes

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I was a child I made scrumptious carrot cake using vegetable oil, but lost the recipe my Mother gave me.  I looked for many years to find another one and tried others not calling for vegetable oil - I found them heavy alternatives.  So I was delighted to find this one, and immediately tried it.  The children and I simply loved this cake.  It was very close if not equal to the one I had.  

Some modifications - I replaced the pecans with raisins, and from a health perspective chose not to make the cream cheese frosting.  I also used cane sugar and reduced the amount added knowing the raisins would provide their own sweetness, and it worked out perfectly.  I will be making this again for sure, and if you try it, the family hopes you also enjoy it.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I used the 'most helpful positive review' and made these changes: 1) using 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar 2) used 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 white flour, 3)added 1T vanilla 4) adding 1 8oz. can of crushed pineapple (drained) 5) Added 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg 6) added 1 extra teaspoon of cinnamon 7) used 3/4 cup canola oil and 1/2 cup applesauce.   I made cupcakes.  Baked at 350 for 15.5 minutes.  It made 31, but they were a little full.  Might be able to stretch out to 3 dozen.  I left pecans out of the frosting, personal preference.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this recipe only 2 stars although the end result was good. I just had to make too many alterations to the original for it to be good. I have to point out though, that us Europeans don't like our pastries as sweet as Americans and that might distort my view of this recipe.

Luckily I read the reviews before I started. I'm sure it would have been awful if I had trusted the recipe blindly. I made a lot of alterations and if I make it again I will be making even more changes. 1) It is WAY too sweet. I cut the sugar for the cake by a fourth and I still think it's too sweet. As someone suggested, I used 50/50 brown sugar and white sugar which was really good 2) I added a teaspoon of vanilla, half a teaspoon of cinnamon, and 1/4 tsp nutmeg. 3) I used less pecans. And the frosting: I cut the sugar by a third and it was still very sweet. I added 3 tbsp lemon juice to make it more balanced.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-01-22T17:07:03.98
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
21333561
Display Name:
Michelle Lim
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made my very first carrot cake with this recipe, and even my fussy hubby said "It's good!". It took exactly 50 min for toothpick came out clean, rose beautifully and did not sink in the middle. The recipe amount fits my springform pan just right (9" wide, 4" tall). I dont like my cakes too sweet, so I used only 2.5 cups of icing sugar for the frosting, and for the batter I cut down oil to 1 cup, replaced 1 cup of white sugar with brown sugar, cut down baking soda to 1 tsp, added 1/2 cup of drained crushed pineapple (from a can) and slightly increased the amt of cinnamon to 2.5 tsp instead. Dont fancy pecans so I caramelised some chopped walnuts and almonds for the topping. But strange the 1/2 cup of walnuts that I added to the batter was close to getting burnt though, not sure why, but good thing it didnt affect our enjoyment of the cake. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
No changes necessary! Everyone loves it

I've made this many times, and usually I will do half brown sugar, half white sugar. I'm not sure it makes a huge difference, and I've done it with white sugar-only several times, too.

People go wild for this carrot cake. I've had many many people tell me things like, "I don't usually like carrot cake, but I like this one!" and "This is the best carrot cake I've ever had." Nothing else I've ever made has ever garnered the praise that this carrot cake does. I'm always embarrassed to tell people it's just 'Carrot Cake III' from AllRecipes.

The amounts listed for the frosting are way too much, though. I've been making this for years, and I'm surprised it hasn't been corrected. Clearly, you shouldn't need 4 cups of confectioners sugar to make frosting for a single cake.

text:
Since I made a lot of changes, it doesn't feel right to give this recipe five stars (even though the cake I made was definitely worthy of that rating). The changes I made are: 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white, +1 teaspoon of vanilla, +1 teaspoon of cinnamon, 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg. I had wanted to use 3/4 cup of oil and 1/2 cup of applesauce since I saw many reviews recommending to do so, but I didn't have any applesauce! So I used the amount of oil listed in the original recipe and it was great! Not oily, just moist and delicious.

Like many of the comments, after making a few adjustments, the cake came out delicious (for the cake: adding 1 extra tsp vanilla, 1/4 nutmeg, instead of 2 cups of white sugar... add 1 cup brown sugar and 1 cup white sugar, and no pecans | for frosting: add 2 1/2 cups of granulated sugar instead of 4 cups) OH AND TIP: if you are using a dark pan, bake at 325 degrees for 45 minutes. And add eggs one at a time into mixture. Overall, it was pure perfection!

Display Name:
Celiac_family_mom
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/624713.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As much as I hate leaving bad reviews, this carrot cake isn't very good.  I made it exactly to specs, and it was mediocre at best.  It also took much too long to cook (over 60 minutes) and, despite using a bundt-style pan, the center was still very gooey and uncooked.   I'm a very experienced baker (almost 40 years of baking), and keep my oven calibrated so I know it wasn't  a temperature issue.  

It also just tasted blah.  Almost had no flavor at all.  I would recommend a couple of teaspoons of lemon extract instead of the vanilla in the cake, using 3/4 cups apple sauce in lieu of the oil, and maybe adding a teaspoon or two each of ground clove, nutmeg,  And allspice in addition to the cinnamon.  

Even the icing was no good as written.   I also made it to specs and let the family taste it before I iced the cake.  No one liked it.  WAAAAY too sweet and no real cream cheese taste.  It was also very thin and wouldn't have spread well.  So I had to add 16 oz. more of cream cheese and about  1 tbsp of cornstarch just to get it stiff enough to spread well without dripping.

text:
My first attempt at carrot cake was a success! I made some of the slight modifications others did to this recipe. I used 3/4 cup oil and 1/2 cup apple sauce, I used half brown and half white sugar, I added a half teaspoon of nutmeg, and I left out the pecans. I baked two cake rounds at 350 for 40 minutes (checked with toothpick). The cake was a huge hit! I will make again except I might be tempted to add some more cinnamon and maybe Allspice next time.

I tried this recipe despite of already having a pretty awesome one...I've got to say it definitely surpass my previous recipe (one I had saved from many years back, not this one).  I did add 1/4 cup of pineapple juice, as well as small pineapples chunks and raisins.  The cake was neither dry nor too moist.  My husbands co-workers raved that it was the best carrot cake they had ever eaten, and suggested I sell this cake!  I usually make carrot cake, when in the mood for carrot juice.  I take advantage of already having  the shavings from my juicer. I'm not trying to one up the original recipe, or take merit from it...that goes to all the negative people who've left bad comments about people changing the recipe...my advice is skip it, you dont HAVE to read it. I incorporate what "I like into what I eat" My notes are for those who've tried the original recipe,  but would be open to make additions that maybe they TOO like. The hostility on here is insane! Let's keep the focus on this recipe, and find something better to do with time.

I used 3 1/2 cups of carrots, and I used 1 cup of white sugar and 3/4 cup of brown sugar. I also omitted the pecans in the frosting, and only used 3 cups of confectioner's sugar. I baked it in a 9'' round pan, then cut it in half and made a layered cake. There wasn't quite enough frosting  to do a crumb coat and a second coat of frosting, but I didn't make more because the frosting was still quite sweet, and I wanted the delicious cake to shine through. The result? moist, delicious, nutty carrot cake.

text:
It's really good but then it better be because it calls for pecans. I was lucky that I had some left over from Christmas. I ran out of icing sugar so I was a little short, so I didn't use as much cream cheese as directed. So, the icing wasn't as thick as it should have been and it wasn't as sweet either. But, all in all, it's a very tasty cake, so the mistakes were barely noticeable.

I would definitely make this carrot cake again, and make sure I have everything for it before I make it.

It's so tasty (I had a taste test) that I want to have my desert for dinner.
PS: I didn't change the recipe on purpose. I ran out of icing sugar. But, with all of the ingredients, it will be amazing.

userID:
20272102
Display Name:
JenniferMP
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I went through reviews, to get a better idea of what to and not to do. I ended up adding 1 cup of apple sauce and instead of the normal amount of oil i used 1/2 a cup of oil, (not including the pineapple people recommended) and then added the 1 cup of brown sugar with 1 cup of regular sugar. I also added in extra teaspoons of vanilla and cinnamon. Then to really jazz it up i shredded the carrots then steamed them to slightly soften (still some crunch) with some brown sugar and cinnamon incorporated in the water. Smelt amazing and made the perfect texture (nobody likes to crunchy of a carrot) I strained most of the water out but left a little bit of the cinnamon sugar water with the carrots to mix into the cake. I also separated the eggs and whipped the egg whites. Folded them into the batter last. The cake turned out delicious with a classic flavor! Paired perfectly with my cream cheese frosting and was easy to frost with, not to crumby very moist! tasted good refrigerated the next day to. I made it for a family gathering and it disappeared. I recommend my alterations to make the perfect cake. Thanks the only thing that could be a preference issue to people is that the cake is on the dense side more.

5

Everyone says it's the best ever!  It's pretty nutty- maybe because I chop them coarsely. I like the texture that gives.  It gets a scrumptious crispness/caramelization on the edges. I've made this recipe probably 20 times as is- twice for friend's weddings.  My husband gets it every year on his birthday- it's a requirement!

None
text:
This cake is super sticky, so if you want to pop it out of a pan, I recommend lining the pan with wax paper. Pam does not cut it. It is not too sweet, which pairs well with the supersweet frosting. I grated the carrots on the same side I use for cheese and it worked well. My cakes did fall despite properly measuring and not overmixing. That is not a big deal if you make the 9x13 as described in the instructions.  Next time I may switch out some of the oil as I felt that caused the sticky edges. The cake tastes great. Seems more like a loaf cake recipe though.

text:
Turned out really good, but really sweet. 
It is probably the same level of sweetness that you would get at a western restaurant, but if that's too much for you (like it is for me), cut down on the sugar level a bit. 
This is after I made the following changes:
1 cup white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar instead of 2 cups white sugar for cake. 
2 cups icing sugar instead of 4 cups icing sugar for the frosting.

text:
This cake was a total hit!  As is, it works wonderfully, but I made it with a few additional changes and everyone said it was the best cake they have ever had.  Biggest changes: a buttermilk glaze and an almond buttercream frosting,  this cake was like no carrot cake I've had before!  Divine!
Details:
(1) - Reduced oil to 3/4 cup and added 1 cup of drained crushed pineapple
(2) - I did two round cakes, and out of the oven drizzled with the following buttermilk glaze and then let cool completely 
*1 cup sugar
*1/2 cup buttermilk
*1 1/2 tsp baking soda
*1/2 cup butter
*1 tb corn syrup
*splash vanilla extract

*****Bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Stir for 4 minutes or until the syrup is light golden.
 
(3) I had a specific request for buttermilk frosting (NO cream cheese) so I tripled the "Quick and Almost-Professional" recipe from Allrecipes with a splash of almond extract and used it for the layered cake.  I was liberal with the frosting, chilled it overnight and it was seriously amazing.

text:
This recipe is great! I made it exactly as the recipe calls for., except I used rapeseed oil since I live in Finland, and we don't have "vegetable oil"here. Everyone who tried the cake, loved it.  The cake itself was very moist. The frosting was very good. The only thing I noticed was that I had WAY too much frosting. There was about a cup left after I was done covering the entire cake in a think layer. The only reason to have that much would be if you are  making 2 layers and need some in between. I just cooked mine in a rectangular pan (9x13in).

I also want to mention that the pecans were great. I really enjoyed the flavor of them in the cake.

text:
This was delicious.  I didn't change anything on purpose, but I did use margarine instead of butter because I didn't realize I was out of butter.  Turned out just fine.  

It was my first time baking carrot cake, the consistency was different than I expected and it didn't rise as much as I thought it would.  I baked this in 2 8-inch cake pans plus still had some for a small loaf pan, I possibly could have pulled off filling the 8-inch cake pans more, but I'm still not sure I could have fit all of the batter in them without them overflowing.  

I also ran low on nuts toward the end.  I didn't have a full cup of nuts for the icing (but did have a full cup in the cake mix) so instead of mixing the nuts into the icing, I just sprinkled them on top, I think I liked that better than if I mixed them in anyway.   I probably won't use a full cup of nuts with the icing in the future either, I think it might be too many nuts then.

text:
Love this recipe, but based on other reviews I do make the following additions  to a full recipe (I would just make a note of these not in a review--for future reference--but the notes function seems to have gone with the old look of Allrecipes):  Made half of the sugar brown sugar, added 8 oz can of drained crushed pineapple, 1/4 tsp nutmeg and an extra tsp of cinnamon.  

This time I made a half recipe for two 6" layers (had some leftovers for a few cupcakes--probably 1/3 recipe would be perfect).  Bake time was then reduced to about 20 min.  I paired this with a full recipe of the frosting (I like my frosting), but would probably reduce that next time to about 2/3 or perhaps 3/4 of the original recipe.

text:
I needed to make a gluten free, egg free dessert so I altered this recipe.  I used 2 cups of rice flour in place of the all purpose flour, 1 cup of unsweetened applesauce in place if the 4 eggs and added 1/2 tsp of baking powder to make a total of 2 1/2 teaspoons of baking powder.  It was great!  no one could believe that it was gf and egg free, everyone loved it. I had made the regular recipe in the past and it was a hit as well. The only thing I would change is the amount of sugar in the icing.  It was a bit too sweet. If it wasn't for the sweet icing I would have given it 5 stars.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-03-27T18:21:04.58
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Excellent cake! If you like cake with a pleasant, not overwhelmingly sweet flavor, this is for you. 

Followed the recipe exactly and it turned out great. I finely shredded the carrots and cooked in two round cake pans @ 350 for 30min.
The cream cheese frosting was a tad thick and hard to spread, but that may have been my fault for not letting it soften quite enough. ;)

My husband, who hated carrot cake after a terrible carrot cake disappointment as a child, quite enjoyed it. ;)

None
text:
Much respect to this recipe but made some changes with the help of other reviews plus dairy intolerance of cheese. Only 2 c of squeezed out carrots (grating size small was ok) with cheese cloth prior marinating with brown sugar. May be able to add only 1 -1.5 c of sugar cause it's sweet. Hydrated 1/2 c raisins with warm rum and pineapple juices. Baked 51 mins. It was heavy with the ingredients, was afraid the cake was going to cake in while cooling but it held up enough. With my dairy intolerance I settled for Swiss meringue with 1t agave syrup,1t vanilla bean paste, 3-5t orange juice- it took it to a orangey cream flavor!

text:
I've never made a carrot cake before (although I've eaten many!) and this is a fantastic recipe. Disclaimer: I used gneebeanie's helpful suggestions and they were spot on.  Instead of frosting the cake with the heavy, sweet cream cheese icing that's typically used on carrot cakes, I used Tom's Whipped Cream Cheese Frosting found on this site...much lighter texture and went very well with the cake. Tammy, thank you so much for sharing this amazing recipe!

I will make this carrot cake again, using olive oil, 1.5 cups of brown sugar (it's darker than white sugar cake), and walnuts.  My husband and I just had a warm piece with frosting, and it was good!  It may be better after being refrigerated so the flavors have a chance to meld, too.  I prefer olive oil, since it is not as greasy as bad-for-us canola or corn oils.

text:
I made this Gluten free & almost dairy free and it was great! It did cave in a little in the middle. I baked it at 350 for 30 minutes in 2 round cake pans. I had trouble getting it out of the pan though I had greased & floured. after it cooled completly I had to hit the pans pretty hard against the counter with the cooling rack on the other side. I used Bobs Red Mill GF Flour that had xatham gum in it. I also used a dairy free cream cheese in a tub for the frosting. I used the large grater holes for the carrots.

I've experimented with carrot cake only twice. It came out great both times. I've decided that this cake is delicious no matter how it is made. It can be altered here and there based on your taste, really; but it still tastes great. One thing I've learned is that this cake tastes better the next day, and even better the third day. I personally add nutmeg and cardamom along with the cinnamon.  It is a cake I think almost anyone would like.

text:
I followed the recipe as written with 3 minor changes which did not affect the true recipe.  The first change was that I did not have enough ground cinnamon so I ended up doing about 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon & 1-1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice.  The second change was that I used walnuts instead of pecans because that's what I had on hand.  The third change was that I used two round cake pans instead of the 9 x 13 as I wanted to make a 4-layer cake.  Everything else, though, I followed exactly (including the frosting).  The cake turned out beautifully!  NOTE:  I used the large grate (like grating cheese) for the carrots and I really pushed them down/compacted them into the measuring vessels.  I wanted to get in as many carrots as I could.  No straining necessary.  
I will post pictures of how it turned out.  It was a delicious!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-02-11T09:40:28.987
helpfulCount:

This carrot cake recipe is the best! I've made it for church functions and other special occasions.  It always gets requested to be made again. It also tastes delicious without the pecans if anyone doesn't like them. One thing that I like most (besides the awesome taste) is that it can be made from things that most people usually have in their kitchen. No special trip to get this dessert done. I'm from the south and I like this recipe without any alterations.

text:
I have made this cake 4 times, exactly as directed. It is very good and everyone loves it. I have had no problems with it being too greasy, or falling as others have. Sometimes it sticks to the pan, but just use parchment paper. It is moist, without too much competing flavour or additions. I specifically chose this recipe because it is a true carrot cake, not pineapple, not raisin etc.  Very good cake, with perfect flavour.  The icing is sweet, but I make it in 2 X9inch pans and layer it and it is perfect. I do not add the chopped pecans in the icing, but decorate with pecan halves instead.  Next time I will try it with applesauce to reduce some oil, but it doesn't need it.
